Text: Surely God is good to Israel, to those who are pure in heart.
Context: This verse affirms God’s goodness to those who are faithful and have pure intentions, setting the theme of the psalm.

Text: But as for me, my feet had almost slipped; I had nearly lost my foothold.
Context: The psalmist expresses a personal confession of near spiritual failure, highlighting the struggle with doubt and envy.

Text: For I envied the arrogant when I saw the prosperity of the wicked.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges feelings of envy towards the seemingly fortunate lives of the wicked, questioning the justice of their prosperity.

Text: They have no struggles; their bodies are healthy and strong.
Context: This verse describes the psalmist‘s perception of the wicked, noting their apparent ease and robust health without moral consequence.

Text: They are free from the burdens common to man; they are not plagued by human ills.
Context: Furthering the observations, the psalmist notes that the wicked seem to avoid the hardships that most people face.

Text: Therefore pride is their necklace; violence covers them like a garment.
Context: The psalmist critiques the wicked, depicting their pride and violence metaphorically as clothing, suggesting an overt and public display.

Text: Their eyes bulge with abundance; they have more than heart could wish.
Context: The verse continues to describe the prosperity of the wicked, suggesting an excess leading to pride or greed.

Text: They scoff and speak with malice; with arrogance they threaten oppression.
Context: The psalmist observes the behavior of the wicked, focusing on their malicious speech and oppressive threats.

Text: Their mouths lay claim to heaven, and their tongues take possession of the earth.
Context: This verse metaphorically speaks to the wicked’s presumptuous speech, as if they had authority over both heavenly and earthly realms.

Text: Therefore their people turn to them and drink up waters in abundance.
Context: The verse suggests that the wicked have a following who absorb their teachings and influence readily.

Text: They say, ”How can God know? Does the Most High have knowledge?“
Context: Expressing the cynicism of the wicked, questioning God‘s knowledge or involvement in worldly affairs.

Text: This is what the wicked are like—always carefree, they increase in wealth.
Context: Summing up the observations of the wicked’s prosperous and seemingly worry-free existence, which causes resentment.

Text: Surely in vain I have kept my heart pure and have washed my hands in innocence.
Context: The psalmist expresses personal doubt, questioning the value of maintaining purity and innocence in light of the wicked‘s success.

Text: All day long I have been afflicted, and every morning brings new punishments.
Context: Contrasting the wicked’s ease, the psalmist shares his own experience of constant suffering and perceived divine retribution.

Text: If I had said, ”I will speak thus,“ I would have betrayed your children.
Context: The psalmist reflects on the consequences of sharing these doubts publicly, recognizing it could lead others astray.

Text: When I tried to understand all this, it was oppressive to me
Context: Expressing the difficulty of comprehending the prosperity of the wicked, it feels burdensome to the psalmist.

Text: until I entered the sanctuary of God; then I understood their final destiny.
Context: The turning point where the psalmist gains perspective by entering God‘s presence, realizing the ultimate end of the wicked.

Text: Surely You place them on slippery ground; You cast them down to ruin.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges that God’s justice will eventually prevail, and the wicked‘s prosperity is temporary and precarious.

Text: How suddenly are they destroyed, completely swept away by terrors!
Context: Describes the swift and complete destruction that befalls the wicked, emphasizing the suddenness of their downfall.

Text: They are like a dream when one awakes; when You arise, Lord, You will despise them as fantasies.
Context: The fleeting nature of the wicked’s success; like a dream forgotten upon waking, insignificant in God‘s judgment.

Text: When my heart was grieved and my spirit embittered,
Context: Recalling the emotional turmoil and bitterness felt by the psalmist during the time of envy and doubt.

Text: I was senseless and ignorant; I was a brute beast before You.
Context: The psalmist’s self-admonition for lack of understanding, comparing himself unfavorably to a senseless animal before God.

Text: Yet I am always with You; You hold me by my right hand.
Context: Despite previous doubts, the psalmist feels reassured by God‘s constant presence and supportive guidance.

Text: You guide me with Your counsel, and afterward You will take me into glory.
Context: The psalmist trusts in God’s wisdom to lead him through life and ultimately into divine glory.

Text: Whom have I in heaven but You? And earth has nothing I desire besides You.
Context: A declaration of complete dependence and desire for God alone, both in heaven and on earth.

Text: My flesh and my heart may fail, but God is the strength of my heart and my portion forever.
Context: Admitting human frailty, the psalmist finds enduring strength and inheritance in God, contrasting with the temporary nature of earthly strength.

Text: Surely those who are far from You will perish; You destroy all who are unfaithful to You.
Context: Reiterating the belief in divine justice, the psalmist states that those distant from God and unfaithful will ultimately be destroyed.

Text: But as for me, it is good to be near God. I have made the Sovereign LORD my refuge; I will tell of all Your deeds.
Context: Ends the psalm on a note of personal commitment to being close to God and proclaiming His works.
